This brought back memories ... When I was a kid in the 80s, monarch butterflies used to attatch their pupa to the underside of the wooden shingles on our house. We'd check them each day before school, and on the day we knew they'd emerge, we'd get to stay home from school and have a picnic in the front yard to watch them come out, and slowly spread their wings. I lived down the street from my school so, after the first time this happened, my entire class got the day off to come down to watch the other times it happened.

We dont know why they randomly chose our house, but this happened for 3 or 4 years before they moved on (most likely due to new home construction next door)

As a country kid I was into caterpillars and butterflies. Mostly the Monarch got my attention and luckily, in Nebraska we had many milkweed plants they loved to eat. I also liked the pods the milkweed would produce. So, one day I decided to get a caterpillar of my own to keep in the house so I could see this process up close. I fed him until he went to pupa stage and then waited, and waited. Every day I watched for changes and even got my older sister in on the observations as I just couldn't sit still all day. So, one day I put her on watch and went exploring along the country road to see what I could find. Just a few minutes into my walk and my sister comes running down the road telling me it's happening and I need to come back to see. I got back just as the butterfly had finished emerging from the pupa and watched as it's wings slowly got bigger and bigger and hardened. Then I released him. Fly away butterfly, fly away to Mexico! I really hoped he made it. Or she, I couldn't tell.

5:18 - No, not like a chameleon. Chameleons don't match the colour of their background, that's a common misconception. They just change tone slightly (typically between brown and green) based on temperature, and (if threatened) try to move to a place where they'll be camouflaged. Cuttlefish and some octopuses, on the other hand, do change colour (and texture) to match their background.

I really enjoy your videos here, but have one question - do all butterflies create pupa in the same way? We have monarch butterflies here in Australia and they love some of our stangler figs that we were growing on out back deck. THey form a very smooth and iridescent shell like structure which is much harder than the ones in your vid. They dont split open, the cut a small hole and push themselves out, forcing the fluid from their bodies into their wings. Is this just a spieces thing?

The flower that your little girl pointed out that 'doesnt follow the rule" looks like a dwarf nasturshum - that little spur at the back fills up with necter like a pitcher plant does, but instead of digesting the bugs that fall in it coats them with necter which makes the pollen stick better to their bodies. With standard nasturshums, which have edible flowers you can pinch off the bottom of that spur and suck out the necter. It is very sweet and tastes how the flower smells!

6:36 Lepidoptera do not pump their meconium into their wings AFAIK. Rather, they pump haemolymph (insect equivalent of blood) into the wings to inflate them. The meconium is composed of waste products (pupae undergo metabolism, but do not have the ability to excrete waste products, so they store them until they can excrete them later). The excreted meconium is not excess fluid that did not fill the wings. It likely squirted when you touched it as a defense - most don't like poop in their mouth.
